title: Gennady Golovkin pushed to limit by Sergiy Derevyanchenko in Garden thriller
text:
Gennady Golovkin was out to make a statement in his first world title fight in more than a year. That’s exactly what happened on Saturday night in New York, though it might not be what the former unified middleweight champion had in mind.

Gennady Golovkin defeats Sergiy Derevyanchenko for IBF middleweight title – live! Read more

Golovkin was pushed like we’ve rarely seen before, looking every bit his 37 years in surviving a heart-stopping challenge from the game Sergiy Derevyanchenko to regain the IBF middleweight champion by a unanimous decision, a verdict that left many in the Madison Square Garden crowd dissatisfied. Ringside judges Eric Marlinski and Kevin Morgan scored it 115-112, while Frank Lombardi had it 114-113. (The Guardian scored it 115-112 to Golovkin.)

“This is huge experience for me,” Golovkin said. “Right now, I understand I need more focus [on] boxing. This was a tough fight. I need a little bit more. I need to still get stronger in my camp. Just more serious. I need to work hard. I need a little bit more focus.”

He added: “Right now it’s bad day for me, it’s a huge day for Sergiy, his team. This is huge experience for me. Right now I know what I need exactly. I lost a little bit of focus. Sergiy was ready. I really respect him. He showed me such a big heart. I told him, ‘Sergiy, this is best fight for me.’ I just respect his team.”

The crowd-pleasing Kazakh dropped Derevyanchenko with a left hand in the first round, then appeared on his way to yet another stoppage win after his opponent suffered a bad cut on his right eye in the second.

But Derevyanchenko, perhaps sensing time was short given the wound, burst from his corner in the third and immediately changed the tenor with aggressive volume punching, rushing pell-mell into the pocket and letting his hands go from a variety of angles.

Golovkin was able to catch Derevyanchenko time and again on the way in, but the 33-year-old from Ukraine was getting the better of the exchanges in the fourth. Both had their moments in the fifth but it was Derevyanchenko who took control late, rearranging Golovkin’s insides with a punishing body shot that sent the Kazakh backwards. (That referee Harvey Dock intervened for no discernable reason left the Derevyanchenko camp furious.)

The Ukrainian poured on the punishment with more body work in the six and by now was outboxing Golovkin, who was appearing to tire. Every time Golovkin was able to land a power shot, Derevyanchenko was there to respond with flurries of punches to the head and body. The two-way action contined into the seventh as both made their stands in the center of the ring, Golovkin doing his best work catching Derevyanchenko on the way in.

Golovkin came on strong in the eighth, bouncing a series of punches off Derevyanchenko’s head as the crowd leaned in for the finish. But he mysteriously let his foot off the gas and his opponenent off the hook, who resumed scoring with angles and activity.

The two-way action continued into the championship rounds as a bloodied Derevyanchenko threw with abandon to the head and body as Golovkin held his ground, an extraordinary and gruesome display. But Golovkin overcame his obvious fatigue to show the finishing kick of a champion in the 12th, snapping his opponent’s head back with clean and accurate punches and winning the final frame on all three judges’ cards to seal the decision.

“Right now it’s bad day for me, it’s a huge day for Sergiy, his team,” said Golovkin, who landed 242 of 720 punches (34%) compared to 230 of 738 for Derevyanchenko (31%). “Right now I know what I need exactly. I lost a little bit of focus. Sergiy was ready. I really respect him. He showed me such a big heart. I told him, ‘Sergiy, this is best fight for me.’ I just respect his team.”

Both were taken to the hospital immediately afterward for precautionary measures.

More to follow.
description: Gennady Golovkin regained the IBF middleweight title with a unanimous-decision win over Sergiy Derevyanchenko at Madison Square Garden
